ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a ton about ethics and biomedical questions have been answered over time
Insights into law
the legal basis behind many important bioethical questions - law approach, not ethical approach
I learned a lot of bioethics issues - from reproductive rights/abortion, to human subjects research, to patents - that are important to consider in the field of science and medicine.

A fascinating survey of the history of medicine, and how its ethical and practical concerns have been addressed (and, sometimes, failed to be addressed) by the law. Great for critical thinking skills.
I learned so much! Lectures covered a variety of topics that I will/have come across in daily life.
The course gives a great overview of a lot of different bioethics issues in the US - from organ transplants, to research with human subjects, to IVF, to abortion.
Bioethics knowledge, how to argue and analyze law
All of the content for the class was super interesting. I had never studied the intersection of medicine, public health and law in this way. It was especially cool to take it during the pandemic.

Learned so much about current topics in bioethics-- ranging from assisted reproduction, to global pandemics, to legal rights to privacy. Was particularly interesting taking this class during a pandemic, as a lot of the later discussion was directly relevant to our lived experience!
Learned about bioethics
I learned about different areas of bioethics law relating to organ donation/transplant, abortion, end-of-life cases, and public health.
I learned a lot about law and ethical questions surrounding medicine.

Knowledge: US healthcare system, bioethics law and important cases in US history, public health
Skills: ability to apply the law and outcomes of certain cases to case studies, ability to understand ethical concerns with certain treatments, procedures, etc.
Insight: the fact that most bioethics law is decided at the state level
Great survey of important cases related to bioethical topics and a solid introduction to medical law.

Knowledge: I learned A LOT in this class about topics that are very relevant to bioethics and society. One of the highlights of the course

Skills: How to write an essay in 30 minutes.
I learned a lot about the ethical decisions behind many medical or biological ideals, and the laws that either supported or undermined these ethical reasonings
I learned a lot about bioethics within the medical industry and loved it!
Great understanding of the law pertaining to major ethical questions in medicine. This legal aspect to bioethics was a great way to approach this after more philosophical bioethics!
I developed knowledge about healthcare systems and a better understanding of the law that governs healthcare in the United States.

I learned a lot about American law and its regulation of various bioethics issues. This course also presented an informative window into medical ethical issues that extend beyond legal coverage in the American system (ranging from topics of the moral and legal status of the developing embryo to end of life care and public health mandates in the time of COVID-19). The material in this course was super relevant to my interests in fertility medicine as a premedical student and the weekly writing requirements for discussion sections and well as the readings strengthened my skills in writing.
I learned about the major themes in bioethics and the most relevant case law on the topic. I also learned how to weigh the ethical implications of the major bioethics questions.
Knowledge about the law and ethics as they apply to healthcare topics
I learned about bio ethical issues.
Learned about a wide variety of issues in bioethics and how the law regulates these issues.
A comprehensive introduction to bioethical issues and the legal questions surrounding them.
I learned about bioethics, how to read legal cases, and how to discuss ethical issues
good understanding of laws and knowledge current issues in Bioethics.

-An understanding of bioethics, including the Belmont Report and the Common rule, and human research standards (IRBs)
-Basics on the Constitution, especially Due Process and the 14th amendment
-An understanding of the American healthcare system and other healthcare systems globally
-Interesting aspects of healthcare that will actually be helpful in making decisions in my own life (understanding the doctor patient relationship, end of life care, abortion/reproductive health, etc.)
I learned a lot about bioethics and how the law and medicine function together.
I learned a ton about bioethics, history and today
I learned about bioethical issues, and the law around them.
I gained a solid understanding of bioethics issues in the states and abroad.

I learned a lot about bioethics and law, and have developed a larger interest in learning about the history of important bioethics cases and the units were well-divided. I feel like I learned a lot and can talk about important landmark US cases with both some constitutional and scientific knowledge, seeing how government works as well as judges.
Learned the state of the law in various bioethics issues, plus the history of how those issues came to develop over time.
Bioethics and the legal side behind it.
This course taught and introduced a plethora of concepts that revolved around bioethics and law. It allowed the integration of scientific knowledge with law.
Analysis of legal writing, drawing arguments through legal cases

I learned how to be effectively understand problems of bioethical law and think about the various court cases and legislation that have influenced the way the United States manages these malleable subjects. I learned that bioethics is tricky and convoluted and driven by many different factors.
Reading and synthesizing laws, cases, philosophies, and historical information.
Exposure to various issues in bioethics such as healthcare/insurance, patient-doctor relationship, informed consent, organ donation, end of life care, abortion, public health
I learned about bioethics and legal systems
I learned about different bioethics issues and got to explore legal cases in depth
I learned about issues in bioethics and how they are treated by the law, and about the relationship between the law and bioethics.

This course provided a broad understanding of the moral and ethical conflicts that emerge in public health, medicine, and law in the United States. I learned how to apply legal cases to a wide array of subject matter.

The ability to break down ethical considerations of biomedical issues and laws. Analyze US law and its application to bioethics issues. How to make an openminded assessment of several perspectives on subjective issues.
I learned a broad overview of bioethics and the main court cases and laws surrounding them.

I learned a lot of the history and legal context of ethical issues in medicine. I feel much more equipped to talk about the basics of the US healthcare system, as well as more controversial topics like abortion, assisted reproduction, gene editing, and other bioethical issues.
Learned a ton about healthcare, doctor/patient relationship, law (history and current), frontiers of bioethics.
Background knowledge of bioethics and how the healthcare system interacts with the law and legal issues
The law (and a little bit of science) surrounding bioethical issues.
I developed a strong background knowledge in a diverse set of bioethics concepts and topics
I learned about various issues in the world of bioethics and their legal applications/histories.
I gained an amazing understanding of the landmark Supreme Court cases that have shaped bioethics law
Knowledge: Bioethics, legal reasoning and comprehension

Bioethics was such a great course! The course's content itself was very interesting but discussion made it even more interesting. This a pretty chill class that always you to learn without worrying about grades. You do need to study for the midterms and final to get a good grade however.
I absolutely loved learning about bioethics law in this course. It is super applicable and useful for every day life and for future careers in the health field.
I learned all about how the American legal system treats bioethics issues.
amazing course even when online!
I learned a lot about the law as it relates to healthcare in the US and ethical questions about healthcare and related topics. I also learned a lot about just the law in general.

This course was a very interesting introduction to bioethics and medical legal cases, and an introduction to law for me. It helped me understand how case law works and progresses, and I improved at reading and understanding legal cases.

I learned a lot more about the complexities and intersections between law and medicine which I had never really thought about too deeply before. It was really interesting to see how much power court decisions have in our day to day lives.
I learned about the history of bioethics and how we got to where we are today in terms of the law surrounding abortion, assisted suicide, etc.
knowledge into us healthcare and legal systems, hot topics in bioethics, learning how to read some legal cases
how to think critically about law and bioethics - true to the name of the class
A lot about cases and laws that shape the medical community. Very engaging and interesting
I learned a lot about current bioethical questions and how they have been dealt with throughout history.
I learned A LOT about the intersectionality of bioethics, law, as well as its political, social, and legal effects! Super interesting class for any major.
I learned a lot about the current status of many bioethics issues, as well as the basic legal and healthcare system of the United States!
Introduction to legal history and background in various issues in bioethics
I learned a lot about the history of bioethics and specifically law regarding bioethics

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lecturer is incredible and section was great too
Recorded lectures are interesting, but short and not posted on time.
It was great material, but it was really hard to concentrate without a live format or powerpoint assistance for lecture (you don't need both, but one of them would have helped).
great course, great content, great professor. I probably got less out of it due to its asynchronous nature, but still really enjoyed it

Strengths: Prof Latham was a really engaging professor and the recorded lecture format worked for me. Also having a wonderful TA who led a great discussion.
Weakness: Sometimes the videos were posted a bit late, so I lost track of which video I was supposed to be watching.

The combo of recorded lecture and discussion section was great for facilitating learning. The weekly reading responses allowed us to cement what we'd learned in lecture and discussed in section, and we were well prepared for all exams.
The textbook is unnecessary and too expensive. It should be taken off the syllabus.
The course was great - the lectures were very clear and informative and section and reading responses were really useful in absorbing the material.

Very cool content
Limited opportunity for prof/student interaction

I would have loved to take this class in person, since the pre-recorded lectures made it feel very un-engaged. I would have loved to attend live lectures with Professor Latham, as he is clearly a talented lecturer.
Very engaging content and Latham is an enthusiastic lecturer. However, sometimes the lectures would be uploaded hours or even days after the scheduled class time, which was kind of inconvenient.

The material was very interesting and easy to follow. Professor Latham laid out the material in a very comprehensive way. For the virtual setting, having lectures posted consistently at the given class time would be my only recommendation for improvement.

Strengths: Professor Latham is a very funny and engaging lecturer (even via prerecorded videos which is so impressive). I learned a lot, not just about bioethics, but about the U.S. legal system more broadly. The material taught in this class is so important and practical beyond the academic context.
Weaknesses: My one qualm was that there were often delays with the uploading of the videos to Canvas, which was frustrating for students who wanted to watch the videos at the scheduled course time. Also, there was a lot of variability in the course depending on the TA. Some were very engaged and provided helpful supplemental materials / review sessions, while others did not.

I think this course was very interesting. I learned a lot and Professor Latham was very comprehensive in lecturing the material. He made legal concepts digestible and I was able to follow everything really well. I thought the class addressed many bioethical concerns in the world and even managed to address the coronavirus crisis that made the course an online format. My only gripe with this course is that I found that it wasn't very consistent in grading. I know many people that took this class and we received grades that were very inconsistent for responses that were likely very similar as we all spent time studying together and making study guides together. Professor Latham said that he would work with TAs to maintain consistency, but this did not translate to reality unfortunately and came to the detriment of some of my friends' grades.

The course would have been improved if lectures were post regularly each week (the schedule was not super organized). Also, the fact that there were no synchronous lectures made it hard to feel connected to the course and my classmates. Still, Prof. Latham is a great professor, very knowledgeable, and provided a really nice overview of bioethics law.
the lectures are short and digestible. Section could be more engaging.

Strengths: lots of interesting material, recorded lectures were engaging, not a demanding work load
Weaknesses: discussion sections can get off track from focusing on the law to discussing people's personal opinions; people can be unwelcoming to certain beliefs in discussion section. Sometimes, the way contentious material is presented in lecture is politically biased.

This was the best virtual course I have taken, and I expect (and hope) that it always will be. Prof. Latham's recorded lectures were of a digestible size and were consistently funny, entertaining, interesting, and I left every single one of them feeling that I had learned something valuable. This semester of PLSC 257 should be a model for how every virtual course should be moving forward.

Strengths: Prof. Latham is a great lecturer. And there is not a huge amount of workload in the class.

Weaknesses: Mandatory section requirement, my TA was unenthusiastic, and the essay-based exams that determine the whole grade seem a bit nerve-wracking.
loved professor lathem and his teaching style, even though it was a recorded lecture he still made each video very entertaining and interesting to watch and learn
A weakness of the course is that it felt like it did require a bit of background on the topics although the course syllabus said it did not. A strength of the course was that it was well organized.

Strengths - Professor Latham is an incredible Professor, very funny, and clearly genuinely cares about his students. 

Weaknesses - I wish that the lecture format could have been a live lecture so that it would have felt less impersonal in this semester of virtual learning and some technical issues might have been avoided.

Strengths: very engaging; great professor
Weakness: none
This class was great!

Professor Latham was often extremely late in posting the videos and occasionally neglected to post them entirely for days at a time. I found this very frustrating, and it seemed like the TFs were also left in the dark about the upload delays as well. Additionally, there was no engagement from Professor Latham beyond these recorded videos. I wish he would have at least popped into section once during the semester. The supplemental readings were almost always mentioned in passing during lectures  the reading was far too much for far too little engagement with them. Supplemental readings posted to Canvas were unorganized, and I found it hard to know exactly what to read for each class because the syllabus was very vague. Course content was very shallow. Many of the exciting nuances about bioethics topics were skipped entirely in favor of broad gestures toward the law.
This is one of the most engaging classes that Ive taken at Yale. The content is super interesting.
I liked the course a lot. Prof. Latham is a great lecturer. I just think that asynchronous lectures make engaging with the course material difficult.
Professor Latham is a great lecturer and makes the content really easy to understand.

Strengths:
-Very interesting material (that made me think critically about my own life choices)
-Engaging lectures that were very informative and well organized
-An active section with a great TA

Weaknesses:
-Recorded lectures are just tough to keep up with in general (I tend to be more motivated when there's a synchronous option)
-Sometimes I wished the grading was more clear (or entered in Canvas) -- I don't really understand the A-/A or B+/A- format of grading, but maybe that's just me
The lectures were very well structured and easy to follow.
This course was fantastic!!!
Recordings are tough to engage with, but also nice because you can listen to them anytime! This course is incredibly TA-dependent (but sort of the nature of a course this large).
Professor Latham was a very engaging lecturer! I enjoyed all of his jokes very much. The sections were also a helpful recap of the lectures.

I definitely think I missed a lot from not being in person because it could get easy to get behind on the lectures. I tried to make up for it by reading the textbook but a lot of the times the assigned reading was too long and hard to remember/understand. I still really liked the discussion and lectures.

Professor Latham is a very engaging lecturer and the class delivers a satisfying overview of the main legal issues of bioethics. Section sometimes feels like a chore and doesn't add much to the class as a whole.
Strengths: The professor and the interesting concepts. Professor Latham is so dedicated to the concepts and passionate about the topics.

Strength: Recorded lectures were so, so, so, so helpful to me. I really needed the ability to rewind or pause to write down notes. I've definitely had one of the highest levels of lecture comprehension in this class, because I was able to go over topics I needed to and subtitles were also really helpful (I'm very much a visual learner rather than auditory). I've also probably taken the best notes I've had in a class because of recorded lectures as well (which were extremely helpful for the exams). I hope that this class will be able to provide a recorded version in future classes, even if it's in person.

This course taught me many valuable lessons about various topics of the health system around the world and various ways by which an ethical system is reasoned and justified. The large number of court cases introduced provided a close connection to the law aspect of bioethics.
Loved this class

Strength: highly interesting and new concepts. Lectures were captivating at every second and well organized.
No weaknesses

Strengths: Professor Latham is really awesome and engaging. The topics are all super interesting and relevant.
Weaknesses: I thought the course was a bit disorganized, because there was some repeated material between lectures and they sometimes didn't feel super planned out. Also, it would be really helpful if there could be a list of the relevant court cases from each lecture because sometimes I didn't know how the cases were spelled as I was trying to take notes.
Strengths: Prof Latham gives fantastic lectures! Weaknesses: none other than that it's difficult to run a big lecture in a virtual setting
Good material. Lectures were clear and engaging

The biggest weakest of the course is that there are no opportunities outside of the exams to improve our grades. I don't believe that the exams are an accurate reflection of how much effort a student puts into the course, especially depending on who your TF is.

The lectures, even though they were recorded, were very engaging and well-organized. I also enjoyed how the course incorporated recent events, including COVID, into the content. Overall, I can't think of how the course could be improvedit even had me considering going to law school!

This course was very thorough and straightforward in the way the material was taught. I appreciated the relevance of the course and the inclusion of a discussion about the pandemic. However, the recorded lecture videos were inconsistently posted and were often not available on canvas by class time, which made planning the rest of the day frustrating. Return of assignments also took longer than expected.

The grading system is really weird. The entirety of our grades is determined by exams, even though we have lots of other work to do. The final should be worth less than 50% and the weekly readings responses should actually count for something! Otherwise it puts wayyyy too much pressure on the exams.
Professor Latham is an excellent professor and does a great job introducing complex bioethics topics to students who have no background in the field.

I thought the recorded lecture format of the class was convenient, and Professor Latham delivered great lectures for us to take notes on. They were clear, concise, contained plenty of details and examples, and offered some personal opinions as well which was refreshing. Sometimes, he was late with his uploads, which was likely a technology issue but made it difficult for students to get caught up before discussion sections. This was the largest issue with the class, but overall, I had a positive experience.

Great instruction, absolutely loved the professors. Thought the readings were a bit much. Also, the discrepancy between the TFs was too big. The TF I had was too harsh in grading, and other TFs were too easy.
I wish we had some intro into how to read legal writings. I frankly could not understand the textbook.

The professor is a very interesting lecturer, the TFs are phenomenal, and the exams are reasonable (and dare I say, even fun?). The concepts are fascinating, and I can see why many people say this is a must-take. But, online I was never able to meet Prof Latham, and I found readings to be fairly unnecessary to actually being engaged and doing well in the class

strengths: interesting material, well-organized in lectures
weaknesses: recorded lecture made it difficult to engage, slides to accompany lectures would've been helpful, as I am a visual learner
Best class Ive taken at Yale!
strengths: very interesting, great lectures, well-organized, clear expectation

I think the recorded lectures were great! The only problem I had was that the videos would show up on Canvas a day or two late and would mess up my schedule. Discussion sections vary by TA. I liked that we were allowed to miss 2 discussion posts (really came in handy this semester).
I wish we had live lectures, but the virtual lectures were done very well and I feel like I truly learned.

Strengths: nice professor, TAs, and cool material
Weaknesses: I wish there were office hours or live lectures, exams didn't really have much guidance on what they were looking for
The content of the course is good, and the lectures went along well with the reading.

This course is very interesting and well taught, and I really enjoyed learning a new subject from Professor Latham. I would say the only weakness was the format of the tests, which were live open note essays, the criteria for which were not always clear, but I assume that was a result of having to be virtual and not standard for the course.

Stephen Latham is a massive strength of this course. Even though it was virtual he was still really engaging and his lectures were fascinating. I appreciated that they were uploaded in 20min chunks rather than an hour and a half of straight information.

A strength was Professor Latham and the content--I felt that he did a great job of explaining things and the content was interesting. A weakness was that there was no real clear guidance on how to do well on the exams.

professor L is a great lecturer very engaging, think readings could be more interesting and cover more sides of issues (e.g. exposing us to the controversial viewpoints or debates rather than summaries)
weakness - lectures being recorded is convenient, but sometimes deviated from the schedule or were posted a few days late, making it hard to plan schedules
Professor Latham is the best and it is so so interesting. No weaknesses. Would have loved to see it live but I liked being able to re-listen to prof Latham in a podcast format!
This is the perfect Yale class in my opinion.

This was a fantastic course. It was typical lecture style. Professor Latham is an awesome professor and makes retaining the information easy. It's a really, really interesting course and would definitely recommend taking it.
Strengths: Interesting material. Well-organized. Amazing professor and TAs.
This course has amazing, fascinating material and Professor Latham is an amazing lecturer but the online recorded lecture format this year was a little less engaging than I had hoped.

Strengths - good introduction to a lot of the legal background of bioethics, great lecturer
Weaknesses - perhaps more grades than just exams would be better; also discussion sections weren't too engaging this semester

This course was relatively low workload, but it would have been nice for the grading to be more reliant on participation in discussion section than just on the midterms and finals. The discussions sometimes fell flat and students didnt show up to section, so I also think itd be more engaging if the lectures were live rather than recordedotherwise it kind of just felt like a lot of work being done on your own.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Videos were comprehensive, funny, and informative 
Wish we could have talked to the professor
I really liked the flexibility of the asynchronous class, but I think I would have learned more in live lectures. Online sections were fine, not ideal.
Made use of prerecording and live sections in the most effective way of any class I've seen. Exams (administered over Canvas with an automatic timer) were convenient to access.
It would have been nice to have a live lecture to engage with.
Professor Latham's recorded lectures were incredibly well done and he did a great job at making the class engaging even though we never actually interacted with him.
Did not like limited prof interaction
I think it would have been more engaging to have live lectures (even though they would have been virtual).
Sometimes the lectures would be uploaded hours or even days after the scheduled class time, which was kind of inconvenient.

I think that the recorded format was very helpful for such a dense subject. Bioethics and the law covers a lot of material and having those lectures to always go back to was very beneficial. However, a live and then recorded format might have been more helpful in order to provide the opportunity for student engagement and questions to be answered.

Succeeded - virtual sections were fine
Could be improved - posting schedule of recorded lectures; review sessions for exams weren't clearly announced/advertised (but recordings were sent out, which was good)
The discussion sections were a great way to engage with the material with classmates.
Succeeded: Recorded lectures allowed us to pace ourselves.
I think that an asynchronous version of this course was very smart, the recorded lectures were hard to follow on real time and i needed to pause it often to take notes.
I think the segmented lectures were fantastic and kept us as far away from zoom as possible, which was much appreciated
The short lectures were very helpful.
As mentioned, I wish the lectures had been a live format rather than recorded. I also wish more detailed feedback on exams had been forwarded to students, rather than just our final grade.
Because this course was recorded lectures, I would have loved if they were all uploaded at the assigned class time, as I do much better sticking to a schedule and I know other students do as well
It was fine

This was a disappointing class. Professor Latham split each module into a series of videos of varying length. But these videos were divided in confusing ways and were uploaded inconsistently. His creativity in having a greenscreen background for each video was welcome, but I would have preferred if he posted the videos on-time and ditched the funky background. Working in this class from California between several other commitments, I found it aggravating that the course content was so sporadic and inconsistent.
I think the synchronous lectures were very successful, but I would have appreciated some form of live lecture.
The recorded lectures were great but it wouldve been nice to also have some in person component with Professor Latham

I highly enjoyed the lectures in this course, but the nature of recorded lectures is that sometimes its difficult to stay motivated enough to stay on track. That said, there were some advantages to this as well-- sometimes, I would be having a really tough academic week, and the recorded lectures allowed me to focus on other coursework during the week, and then watch lectures on the weekends (and still retain the same amount of knowledge, but at my convenience). Also, the nature of having a weekly reading response and 2 midterms made it nearly impossible to fall too far behind. I always caught up with lectures by the start of section, simply because I had to know topics in order to write reading responses.
It was great, would have justr been better if lectures were always posted on time
The flexibility provided by the recorded lectures was very helpful.
Discussion sections meeting were fun but I think that the recorded lectures werent all the best because I wish I could have engaged with Professor Latham more.
The recorded lectures succeeded. The videos were very concise.
All the practices made due to COVID-19 were successful.
The lectures were engaging and the online exam format was fair
I liked the pre recorded lecture style. It allowed me to watch the lectures during my time and really comprehend the material
I believed virtual section was helpful (despite my TF cancelling section several times throughout the course).
It would have been nice to have some live interaction with the professor, since our only interaction with him was through recorded lectures.
Flexibility and understanding from TAs was effective. Often times it felt impersonal because of the pre-recorded nature.

While I definitely missed experiencing Professor Latham lecture live, I think the prerecorded videos were very successful in allowing for maximum flexibility during the pandemic. Additionally, having the midterms and final open for 24 hours worked well also.
The recorded lectures could have been more timely. Otherwise, I thought the class adapted well to the pandemic.
Recorded lectures were useful but I felt disconnected from the professor. Having a section was nice in that sense.

Sections were great and exams (open book open note, but timed, on canvas) were reasonable. I wish there was more interaction with the professor and with other students though, even if it couldve been zoom lectures
Section was a nice space to discuss lecture content. Reading responses also helped prepare me for the exams.

recorded lectures were helpful but also made course engagement hard. weekly reading responses were not well-timed with the release of lectures and my early section (monday night), making those more difficult and less valuable. we also had to wait a long time for feedback, which was not very helpful.
The recorded lectures were great

Discussion section was the best part of this course. Especially with Chaaru. The virtual lectures were very well done, but I wish they had been live lectures. I wish I had been able to see actual feedback on my exam responses.
I really wish there was some sort of live component with the professor.
The asynchronous lectures were really well done! Professor Latham split them up well and did a great job making them manageable. The sections were also helpful.

The "fun size" lectures were much more digestible than hour long monologues! I also appreciated having an in person weekly discussion to engage with the material more. I wish we had more chances to chat with Dr. Latham himself but I understand that the circumstances didn't really support those types of interactions.
i loved asynchronous lectures though a live option everyonce in awhile might be nice
Professor Latham did a great job

The lectures were exactly as long as they needed to be, discussion question assignments actually helped me think about what we were learning, discussion  sections were useful and engaging, and there were plenty of resources for everything.
The only thing I didn't like was how vague and arbitrary grading on the first midterm was.
I personally really loved the pre-recorded video lectures; the weekly discussion section also helped reaffirm knowledge.
I think the weekly discussion sections really facilitated discussion about class material and encouraged me to think more deeply about what we learned.

Succeeded - lectures were still quite engaging
Improved - but lectures could still use more visuals, like a powerpoint slide to accompany them. Also, discussion sections could use more engagement even in a virtual setting
Discussion section worked well, and I liked that the lectures were recorded, but I thought they could have been delivered live and the recording could have been optional.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. I am taking it as a second semester senior, and I have really enjoyed the content. Workload is low and the information is interesting, which is rare.
YES! Take this course. It's an excellent overview of the bioethics topics that affect our society today. Professor Latham does an excellent job discussing the cases and their implications.
Absolutely, learned a lot about the interplay between national health in the United States, global health, and the law.

Yes! A great course for students from all majors + walks of life. The Public Health module in particular has so many real-world implications, given the pandemic, and offered up angles I'd never before considered. That rare class where you learn something of substance without undue stress/an overwhelming workload.
Yes definitely!
Absolutely!  It's super informative and interesting.
Yes

I would recommend taking this course Cr/D. The material was very interesting, and discussion section was full of different opinions and debate, but the exams are graded pretty subjectively. My TA literally said that the differences between an A, A-, and B+ were very slim. It's difficult to excel, but it's also difficult to do poorly. The subject matter was really very fascinating though.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this class, as it was super interesting and a really low workload. It will probably be a lot more enjoyable in person as well.
Absolutely-- both interesting and low workload. Great 5th class.
Yes, this class is very interesting and easy workload.

I would definitely recommend this class. Professor Latham is a very funny and engaging lecturer (even via prerecorded videos which is so impressive). I learned a lot, not just about bioethics, but about the U.S. legal system more broadly. The material taught in this class is so important and practical beyond the academic context.
Yes. Latham is an engaging instructor even if it was all virtual.

I would definitely recommend this class to other students. It is very interesting material and Professor Latham is a very intelligent man that has worked in the field of bioethics in the past. I did think the material was interesting, however, my primary motivation in taking this course was its popularity. I'm not sure if it was the online format, but I found that this course fell short of the raving reviews it has. I wish I could have experienced this class in person as discourse with students and Latham in a live environment would like make this course ten times better.
I would recommend to a student who wants a good, broad overview of different bioethics/legal issues.
Yes! Its relatively easy and super interesting!
Yes, easy course and great way to learn about a lot of interesting bioethics topics.

Absolutely. This course is interesting, useful, has fair exams, and ended up being my favorite course of my entire first year (saying this as a math major!). Professor Latham is amazing at what he does, and he picks great TFs to run the discussion sections. Take this class!
Yes. It is probably one of the best classes at Yale in terms of content.
absolutely recommend. it is easily the most interesting class I have taken at Yale
Yes! Amazing material
Yes. Wonderful background to the law.
Yes but it is helpful to have some prior knowledge about healthcare law and healthcare systems.

Absolutely  everyone should take this course (regardless of whether you are interested in going into medicine or public policy, a solid foundational understanding of the legal precedent on some of the most contentious issues in our national discourse ranging from the abortion debate to stem cell research afforded by this course is invaluable).
Yes! The material is so interesting and Professor Latham is engaging.
Definitely! One of the best classes at Yale, hands down.

Not online. Bioethics is fascinating, and the reading proved to be incredibly interesting, but the work expectations seemed pointless. Why assign 100+ pages of a dense casebook on top of a smattering of supplemental readings on top of weekly discussion posts, only to never discuss the readings? You're not even graded on these discussion posts. They don't factor into your grade at all. I don't think I ever received a grade in this class. I had to ask my TF after section to get a vague answer for my midterm grades. Never received detailed feedback. It seemed like Professor Latham was negligent in answering my TF's questions, because it seemed like even he was puzzled about what was going on in the class logistically.
Yes
Yes, absolutely! Very interesting material without a grueling work load.
Definitely, Professor Latham is an awesome professor and the class is very interesting.
Yes! I absolutely loved this class! The material was very interesting and the exams were very fair.
This is a really interesting course, and Professor Latham is a great lecturer.
Absolutely, Professor Latham is great and makes concepts really easy to understand

Yes! In my opinion, everyone should take the opportunity to learn the material in this course, because it directly relates to your life in some way. I had never thought about what choice I would make in certain medical situations before this course, and now I feel like I have a better understanding of my own ethics when it comes to healthcare. Professor Latham is extremely knowledgeable, and is an engaging speaker who clearly cares about student learning. I would recommend this course to anyone!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. If you are interested in medicine, law, or simply want to be more informed for your own life, this class is a must-take. You learn a lot about why the US functions the way it does when it comes to medicine.
Absolutely! Fantastic course, Professor Latham is awesome and it is so interesting!!
I think this is a quintessential course, but tough to take virtually. Again, super TA-dependent.
Yes! You get to think critically about bioethics issues and come to your own conclusions. The instructors were all very engaging and accomodating.
Yes definitely!! I feel like I learned so much and could take it as a fifth class.
Yes! Bioethics is a very easy class where you still learn a satisfying amount about interesting subjects.

Yes! It opened a whole different perspective on topics such as healthcare, abortion, assisted reproduction, assisted death, organ donation, and public health. it a MUST TAKE class for all Yale students and I highly recommend it.

Yes, I would definitely recommend. I finally understood the healthcare landscape, and each bioethics issue was so interesting. The court cases were also a really nice way for me to analyze this type of literature.
Yes, I will certainly recommend this course to another student. I enjoyed many aspects of it. The lectures were great.
Definitely, I feel like everyone should know on some level the legal cases surrounding health that affect us all.

Yes! This class made me think so differently about health as it relates to law, ethics, myself, and the world population. Professor Latham is an incredible professor, and the topics are both appropriate and fascinating.
Yes absolutely!! The topics covered are all really interesting and relevant. Additionally, Professor Latham is a great lecturer (even through recorded lectures, I felt engaged).
Yesit's fun and you learn a lot about the legal system
Yes! Great class. Professor is very knowledgeable

Honestly, I'm not sure if I would recommend this course to another student. Prof. Latham was an excellent lecturer, and I truly enjoyed reading the course materials. However, I didn't appreciate that our grades were completely dependent on the exams, especially given that my TF cancelled the three or so "mandatory" sections leading up to the final exam worth 50% of the grade (and he refused to host a study session before the exam).
Would definitely recommend for anyone! A fascinating and very applicable course that is not too difficult or heavy in terms of workload.

Yes, I would! It is super interesting and super relevant. I think it will make students consider things that they hadn't necessarily otherwise considered. It reveals a lot of the nuances with medicine and law that typically are overlooked. I think if a student is interested in the way precedent case determine a lot of the logic that is used today they would be successful in this course.

Yes, I would recommend this course to everyone because the issues discussed are not only pertinent to the field of bioethics, law, and legislation but because they concern issues that most people will face in their life eventually. The professor did a great job of framing the topics of this course in this way to highlight their overall importance in helping people determine where their values align when it comes to bioethics issues.
Probably. I would warn them about the final being 50% of our grade and the weekly reading responses not counting for a grade but still being mandatory.
Yes! I absolutely loved this course and would recommend it to anyone!

Definitely. This class is very relevant to anybody interested in medicine and politics, as well as anybody who has an interest in engaging in recreation political discussion. I thought the class did a great job covering high-level concepts and properly discussing more landmark cases, like Roe vs Wade, in detail. The course also gave a lot of good supplementary readings for those who are more interested, and discussion sections were a great opportunity to discuss and learn more.
Definitely. Very informative - I came out of the class knowing a lot more about the healthcare system and bioethics.
Yes, if you are interested in this kind of subject. Prof. Latham is great. Wouldn't take it if you just want a 5th credit; your grade is too dependent on what TF you have for it to be a gut.
I would recommend this to another student who is looking for a low-stress Credit/D/F. The course material is also quite interesting.
Easy A-, but you have to work for the A.
Yes! I think its a really well-done class and the concepts are super interesting and applicable to know
Absolutely! Interesting (and increasingly relevant) content, delivered in an engaging way. 10/10.
yes, if you're interested in the material
Absolutely! So interesting
YES-great lectures and manageable workload
Yes! Important and interesting topics
yes!

Yes!! The workload isn't too bad, but you do have to put in work to get an A in the class. The course is very interesting and you get the chance to talk about different medical issues that are prevalent in our society today.
Yes!! It's so useful for anything health related and is taught super well! You'll have a good time in this course.
Yes!  Really cool stuff.  I definitely recommend this course to anyone thinking about law school because you can set this course up to treat it like a law course with the casebook and outlining.
For sure!!! A Yale classic
Yes I would, especially if you are interested in learning about law and/or bioethics and want a simple class where you can do that.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! Its a great and low stress way to learn about bioethics and law form Professor Latham, a true expert, and is very interesting without having too heavy a workload.
YES! You learn so much about important and topical subjects in a low pressure environment. The course was extremely enjoyable online so I can't even imagine how great it is in person:)

It's a great class to take Credit/D/Fail; I feel like I got to learn a lot about bioethics when I otherwise wouldn't have been able to. It might be difficult to pull out an A, though. It's not necessarily a gut.
definitely - super super super interesting w relatively low work, u think u know ab us health and legal systems but dont really, viewpoints may be changed
Absolutely! Very interesting, very well taught, manageable workload. Its nice not to worry about endless assignments and genuinely enjoy the content
Absolutely, everyone should take this course.
Yes absolutely! Like I said, Professor Latham is absolutely wonderful and the course content is really interesting.
Yes
YES!!! 100% take this class!!!
I would definitely recommend this course to another student! I will remember a lot of the topics we covered, and as a pre-med student, I believe I gained a lot of important perspective.
Yes!
Yes. The lectures are very clear and easy to follow and the material is interesting and relevant. If you are looking for an easy fifth class this is it
I would recommend this course to another student, but would warn them that the grading of the course is not super forgiving since the only grades are three exams.

Yes!!! Prof. Latham is a great lecturer, even recorded. Hes entertaining and provides just the right amount of information ona topic. Its a gutty class, but be warned that the midterms/finals are graded a bit harshly sometimes. So even though its low workload and also really interesting material, its important to not completely slack off since the final is 50% of your grade.
